title: Scalars and vectors - adding vectors graphically

content.question: <math alttext="vector A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover accent="true"><mi>A</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math>, <math alttext="vector B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover accent="true"><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math>, <math alttext="vector C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover accent="true"><mi>C</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math>, and <math alttext="vector D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover accent="true"><mi>D</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math> are vectors which have equal magnitudes but point in different directions, as shown in the figure. Which of the following resultant vectors has the greatest magnitude?

choices.label: <math alttext="vector A plus vector B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover accent="true"><mi>A</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>+</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math>
<math alttext="vector C minus vector D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover accent="true"><mi>C</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>−</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>D</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math>
<math alttext="vector B plus vector D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover accent="true"><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>+</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>D</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math>
<math alttext="vector C minus vector A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover accent="true"><mi>C</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>−</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>A</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="vector C minus vector A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover accent="true"><mi>C</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>−</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>A</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math>

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
